metadata.titleEn: High spatial  resolution (10km) surface solar radiation dataset with by merging sunshine hours over China China (1983-2017)
metadata.description: This data set is a national high-resolution solar radiation data set covering 34 years (1983.7-2017.6), with a resolution of 10 km. The data unit is W / m2. The data set is developed by merging  the global high-resolution (3 hours, 10 km) surface solar radiation data set (1983-2017) with isccp-hxg cloud products as the main input, with ground based sunshine duration derived surface solar raidation data from 2261 meteorological stations in China by using the geographic weighted regression method. The validation results  show that this dataset can provide more accurate simulation of long-term variability of surface solar radiation than that of gewex-srb, cmsaf-clara-a2 and the isccp-hxg based surface solar radiation  product. This data can provide favorable data support for the application and research of long-term change of hydrology in land surface process simulation.
metadata.instructions: This data is in NetCDF format and contains 6 variables. The recordid is the record number. RS is the surface solar radiation data. Latitude and longitude are latitude and longitude. Month and year are months and years. For more information about NetCDF, see http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/software/netcdf.

background: Long-term changes in surface solar radiation (Rs, spectral range of 0.3–3.0 µm) with a decrease (global dimming) from the 1950s to the late 1980s and a subsequent increase (global brightening) have been observed worldwide. Global dimming and brightening inevitably lead to energy balance changes and have substantial impacts on land surface climate, hydrologic cycle, carbon cycle and human activity. Direct observations can provide accurate Rs records. Before 1990, the USSR pyranometer imitations had different degradation rates in the thermopile, resulting in an important sensitivity drift. To overcome radiometer aging, China replaced its instruments from 1990 to 1993. However, the new solar trackers frequently failed and introduced a high missing data rate for the direct radiation component of Rs. After 1993, although the instruments were substantially improved, the Chinese-developed pyranometers still had a high thermal offset with directional response errors, and the stability of these instruments was also worse than that of the World Meteorological Organization (WMO)-recommended first-class pyranometers. Since the 1960s, the possibility of estimating Rs from satellites has been examined in many studies. Due to the capability of capturing the spatial distribution and dynamic evolution of clouds from satellite data, satellite-derived Rs products have long been recognized as better methods to estimate regional and global Rs than numerical modeling. The trend of Rs derived from satellites has been shown to be consistent with ground observations but differs in sign and magnitude. Satellite Rs products based on the early version of the ISCCP cloud dataset show quite different interannual variations in Rs from 1984 to 2000, which are only approximately one half to one third of the direct Rs surface observations over China. The surface sunshine duration (SunDu) is the sum of the time for which the ground surface is irradiated by a direct solar irradiance beam exceeding a certain threshold (usually 120 W/m2) and is considered to be a reliable proxy of Rs. SunDu has been used as reference data to adjust the inhomogeneity of direct observations over China. Previous studies further demonstrate that SunDu can be used as a reliable proxy for direct Rs observed data to reconstruct long-term Rs. The previously mentioned inhomogeneity adjustment methods mainly focus on Rs data over observation sites, and the adjustment processes are generally “point to point” corrections. Comparatively, inhomogeneities in the satellite Rs gridded data have attracted little attention due to the lack of reliable Rs reference data with large spatial coverage.
research objective: To adjust the inhomogeneity of the satellite Rs products, we propose a geographically weighted regression fusion method (HGWR) to merge ISCCP-HXG Rs with SunDu-derived Rs.
challenges: However, the three AVHRR-based satellite Rs products have significant biases in quantifying the trend of Rs from 1983 to 2016 (−4.28 W/m2/decade to 2.56 W/m2/decade) due to inhomogeneity in satellite cloud products and the lack of information on atmospheric aerosol optical depth.
methods: First, we use direct Rs observations and SunDu-derived Rs to assess the performances of these long-term satellite Rs products, including CMSAF CLARA-A2 (CMSAF), GEWEX-SRB (GEWEX) and ISCCP-HXG (HXG), over China, especially for the long-term Rs trends. Geographically weighted regression (GWR) is used as a fusion method to merge the ISCCP-HXG-derived Rs with ground-based SunDu-derived Rs (HGWR). All the 121 direct Rs observation sites, where both direct observed Rs data and SunDu-derived Rs data are recorded, are used as validation sites, and the remaining 2261 sites are merged with HXG by GWR.
dataset: SunDu-derived Rs is available from the 1960s at more than 2000 stations over China, which provides reliable decadal estimations of Rs.
findings: The merged Rs product over China from 1983 to 2017 with a spatial resolution of 10 km produces nearly the same trend as that of the SunDu-derived Rs. This study makes a first attempt to adjust the inhomogeneity of satellite Rs products and provides the merged high-resolution Rs product from 1983 to 2017 over China, which can be downloaded freely.

Definition.Question: What does 'SunDu-derived Rs' mean in relation to estimating surface solar radiation?
Definition.Answer: SunDu-derived Rs refers to surface solar radiation estimates derived from sunshine duration data, which measures the time the ground is irradiated by direct solar irradiance above a certain threshold, considered a reliable proxy for reconstructing long-term Rs data.

Definition.Question: What does 'inhomogeneity adjustment' imply when discussing satellite Rs data?
Definition.Answer: Inhomogeneity adjustment in the context of satellite Rs data refers to the process of correcting inconsistencies or biases in satellite-derived surface solar radiation data by using reliable reference data, such as SunDu-derived Rs, to ensure the data accurately reflects long-term trends.

Comparison.Question: How does the geographically weighted regression method used for merging satellite-derived Rs with ground-based SunDu-derived Rs compare to traditional point-to-point correction methods in terms of addressing inhomogeneity in Rs datasets?
Comparison.Answer: The geographically weighted regression method provides a spatially continuous adjustment by merging satellite-derived Rs with SunDu-derived Rs, unlike traditional point-to-point corrections, which are typically applied directly at observation sites. This approach addresses inhomogeneity more comprehensively by using a broader spatial context.

Comparison.Question: How does the validation performance of merged Rs products over China compare when using direct Rs observations versus SunDu-derived Rs as reference datasets, given the long-term trends from 1983 to 2017?
Comparison.Answer: The merged Rs product over China from 1983 to 2017, when validated against both direct Rs observations and SunDu-derived Rs, shows nearly the same trend as that of the SunDu-derived Rs, suggesting that SunDu-derived Rs is a reliable reference for accurately capturing long-term trends.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges in data collection are revealed by the biases in AVHRR-based satellite surface solar radiation products when assessing long-term trends?
Interpretation.Answer: The significant biases in AVHRR-based satellite surface solar radiation products highlight challenges such as inhomogeneity in satellite cloud products and the lack of atmospheric aerosol optical depth information, which affect the accuracy of trend quantification from satellite data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a significant bias in the trend estimation of Rs from certain AVHRR-based satellite products?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The significant biases in quantifying the trend of Rs from 1983 to 2016 are due to inhomogeneity in satellite cloud products and the lack of information on atmospheric aerosol optical depth.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the higher precision of the merged Rs product compared to other global satellite radiation products in long-term trend simulations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The higher precision is attributed to the use of geographically weighted regression to merge ISCCP-HXG Rs with SunDu-derived Rs, which provides a more accurate long-term trend simulation than other satellite radiation products.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using geographically weighted regression fusion methods in merging satellite-derived and ground-based solar radiation data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using geographically weighted regression fusion methods can adjust the inhomogeneity of satellite Rs products, resulting in a merged high-resolution Rs product that reflects trends similar to those derived from ground-based SunDu data, providing more reliable data for long-term surface solar radiation studies in China.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to address the inhomogeneity in satellite solar radiation data products when developing high-resolution datasets?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Addressing inhomogeneity in satellite solar radiation data products is essential to produce more accurate and reliable long-term trends of solar radiation over large spatial areas, as inconsistencies can lead to significant biases in trend quantification.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are necessary to integrate surface sunshine duration data with satellite-derived solar radiation data for creating a high-resolution dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A geographically weighted regression fusion method (HGWR) is used to merge ISCCP-HXG Rs with SunDu-derived Rs. Direct Rs observations and SunDu-derived Rs are assessed for long-term satellite Rs products, and the remaining sites are merged with HXG by GWR.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the biases in satellite-derived solar radiation products be addressed to improve the accuracy of long-term trend analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Significant biases in AVHRR-based satellite Rs products are adjusted by employing a geographically weighted regression method to merge satellite-derived Rs with SunDu-derived Rs, offering a more reliable trend analysis.

Enablement.Question: What conditions have enabled the use of geographically weighted regression methods for merging satellite-derived and ground-based solar radiation data?
Enablement.Answer: The availability of both direct Rs observations and SunDu-derived Rs data at a significant number of sites across China enables the use of geographically weighted regression methods to merge satellite-derived and ground-based solar radiation data.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of SunDu-derived radiation data enhance the accuracy of satellite-based solar radiation estimations?
Enablement.Answer: SunDu-derived radiation data provides reliable decadal estimations and serves as a reference to adjust the inhomogeneity of satellite Rs products, thereby enhancing their accuracy.

Enablement.Question: What resources or data are necessary to address the inhomogeneity challenges in satellite-derived solar radiation products?
Enablement.Answer: To address inhomogeneity challenges, it is necessary to have reliable reference data like SunDu-derived Rs, which allows for the adjustment of satellite Rs products using methods such as geographically weighted regression.

Expectation.Question: Why might satellite-derived solar radiation products exhibit significant biases in trend estimation over time?
Expectation.Answer: Satellite-derived solar radiation products have significant biases due to inhomogeneity in satellite cloud products and the lack of information on atmospheric aerosol optical depth.

Expectation.Question: Why is it expected that SunDu-derived solar radiation data provides reliable long-term estimates?
Expectation.Answer: SunDu-derived solar radiation data is considered reliable because it has been used successfully as a proxy for direct solar radiation observations, providing consistent decadal estimations at over 2000 stations across China.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the effectiveness of using geographically weighted regression fusion methods in addressing the inhomogeneity of satellite-derived surface solar radiation data?
Judgmental.Answer: The geographically weighted regression fusion method is evaluated as effective for adjusting the inhomogeneity of satellite-derived surface solar radiation data. It allows for the merging of satellite-derived data with ground-based data, producing a high-resolution dataset that aligns closely with ground observations, as demonstrated in the merging of ISCCP-HXG Rs with SunDu-derived Rs.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the challenges posed by the biases in AVHRR-based satellite products in accurately quantifying long-term trends of surface solar radiation?
Judgmental.Answer: The biases in AVHRR-based satellite products present significant challenges in accurately quantifying long-term trends of surface solar radiation, ranging from -4.28 W/m2/decade to 2.56 W/m2/decade. These biases are attributed to inhomogeneity in satellite cloud products and the lack of atmospheric aerosol optical depth information, which necessitate robust correction methods like geographically weighted regression for reliable long-term trend analysis.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the potential for SunDu-derived surface solar radiation data as a reliable proxy for reconstructing long-term radiation trends?
Judgmental.Answer: SunDu-derived surface solar radiation data is considered a reliable proxy for reconstructing long-term radiation trends. It provides reliable decadal estimations of Rs, with data available from more than 2000 stations since the 1960s, and has been effectively used as reference data to adjust the inhomogeneity of direct observations in China, leading to a high-resolution dataset that mirrors observed trends.

The performance of long-term satellite Rs products is assessed using direct Rs observations and SunDu-derived Rs. All direct Rs observation sites with both direct observed Rs data and SunDu-derived Rs data are used as validation sites, while the remaining sites are merged using GWR.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges related to satellite Rs products in quantifying long-term trends.

These challenges affect the accuracy of long-term trend estimations.
